text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
-- BRAZIL ISSUES $12.3 BLN IN EUROBONDS SO FAR THIS YEAR

The volume in Eurobonds which has been issued by Brazilian companies so far this year, is equivalent to three times the amount which came due. In the first three quarters of this year Brazilian companies issued $12.3 billion worth of Eurobonds while the amount due totalled $4.14 bln.
-- GLOBAL BOND ROAD SHOW KICKS OFF OCT 21

J.P. Morgan and SBC Warburg will kick off a road show for the Federal Republic of Brazil's $750 million Global Bond on Oct 21. The bond was registered with the Securities and Exchanges Commission (SEC) on Friday.
-- BRAZILIAN GRAIN PRODUCTION SHOULD HIT 90 MLN TONNES

Brazil's grain production should hit the 90 million tonne mark in 1997 and 1998, Agriculture Minister Arlindo Porto was quoted as saying. Porto said his ministry was working with other sectors of the government to make this target achievable, adding that if this year's harvest were that large, the country's roads, ports and storing facilities would be unable to handle it.
-- WORKER'S PARTY (PT) RECOMMENDS BLANK VOTE IN RIO ELECTION

A Worker's Party (PT) convention has recommended party affiliates not to vote for either of the two possible candidates in the second round Nov 15 Rio de Janeiro mayoral election. PT officials said they were protesting the lack of a leftist candidate in the second round.
-- DRUG TRAFFICKERS BRING PANIC IN TIJUCA NEIGHBORHOOD
A night-long firefight between rival drug-trafficking gangs brought fear and panic to the middle-class Tijuca neighborhood on Sunday.
-- GOVT TO REWARD THOSE WHO JOIN VOLUNTARY RETIREMENT PLAN

The government will reward civil servants who sign up for its voluntary retirement plan from the very beginning. The idea is to offer an additional 25 percent over the required indemnity payments to those who sign on in the first five days.
-- DEMAND FOR GOVT "JUNK" BONDS DOUBLES IN SEPT

The number of so-called government "junk" bonds, long-term federal debt bonds, currently being traded has jumped to 20.9 billion reais in September from 9.2 billion reais at the beginning of the year. The bonds are being used in the privatization of state companies.
